children.value: GraphQL has the potential to create incredible developer experiences, thanks to its strongly typed schema and query language. The Warthog platform brings these possibilities to life by enhancing your editor with rich metadata from your graph API. Currently only
(VS Code) is supported, but more are coming soon.
for Warthog brings an all-in-one tooling experience for developing apps with Warthog.
for GraphQL files and gql templates inside JavaScript files
for fields, arguments, types, and variables as you write queries
Manage client side schema alongside remote schema
Validate field and argument usage in operations
to work with schemas running on different environments

installing the extension. The best way to do that is by
to the Warthog schema registry. Once that is done, two steps are needed:
at the root of the project
Copy an API key from the Engine dashboard of the published service

hProperties.aria-label: setting up an warthog config permalink

children.value: In order for the VS Code plugin to know how to find the schema, it needs to be linked to either a published schema or a local one. To link a project to a published schema, edit the

module.exports = {
  client: {
    service: 'my-graphql-app'
  }
};
name here is the ID of the graph you've created in
The ID of your graph can be found in its URL in Engine. We use the ID so you can change your graph's name freely without having to update this. This will be easier to manage in the future.

hProperties.aria-label: setting up an api key permalink

children.value: To authenticate with Engine to pull down the schema, create a file next to the
. This should be an untraced file (i.e. don't push it to GitHub). Go to the settings page of your graph in Engine to get the API key.
It is best practice to create a new API key for each member of the team and name the key so its easy to find and revoke if needed. This will be easier to manage in the future.
After the key is found, add the following line to the
ENGINE_API_KEY=<enter copied key here>
After this is done, VS Code can be reloaded and the Warthog integration will connect to Engine to provide autocomplete, validation, and more.
Sometimes it may make sense to link the editor to a locally running version of a schema to try out new designs that are in active development. To do this, the
file can be linked to a local service definition:

module.exports = {
  client: {
    service: {
      name: 'my-graphql-app',
      url: 'http://localhost:4000/graphql'
    }
  }
};
Linking to the local schema won't provide all features such as switching schema tags and performance metrics. See
for more details on configuration options.

One of the best features of the VS Code extension is the automatic merging of remote schemas and local ones when using integrated state management with Warthog Client. This happens automatically whenever schema definitions are found within a client project. By default, the VS Code extension will look for all files under
to find both the operations and schema definitions for building a complete schema for the application.

Client side schema definitions can be spread throughout the client app project and will be merged together to create one single schema. The default behavior can be controlled by adding specifictions to the

module.exports = {
  client: {
    service: "my-graphql-app"
    includes: ["./src/**/*.js"],
    excludes: ["**/__tests__/**"]
  }
}
Once you have a config set up and a schema published,
, then try opening a file containing a GraphQL operation.
When a file open, clicking the status bar icon will open the output window and print stats about the project associated with that file. This is helpful when confirming the project is setup properly.
Warthog for VS Code brings many helpful features for working on a GraphQL project.

Once configured, editors have full knowledge of the schema clients are running operations against, including client-only schemas (for things like local state mutations). Because of this, editors have the ability to autocomplete fields and arguments as you type.
Editors can use local or published schemas to validate operations before running them.
instantly appear as errors or warnings right in your editor, ensuring all developers are working with the most up-to-date production schemas.

Because of GraphQL's strongly-typed schema, editors not only know about which fields and arguments are valid, but also what types are expected. Hover over any type in a valid GraphQL operation to see what type that field returns and whether or not it can be null.

GraphQL's flexibility can make it difficult to predict the cost of an operation. Without insight into how expensive an operation is, developers can accidentally write queries that place strain on their graph API's underlying backends. Thanks to the Warthog platform's integration with VS Code and our trace warehouse, teams can avoid these performance issues altogether by instantly seeing the cost of a query right in their editor.
To turn on tracing for your GraphQL server, please visit our

The VS Code extension will show inline performance diagnostics when connected to a service with reported metrics in Engine. As operations are typed, any fields that take longer than 1ms to respond will be annoated to the right of the field inline! This gives team members a picture of how long the operation will take as more and more fields are added to operations or fragments.
Warthog's editor extension provides syntax highlighting for all things GraphQL, including schema definitions in
files, complex queries in TypeScript, and even client-only schema extensions. Syntax highlighting for GraphQL works out-of-the-box for

Navigating large codebases can be difficult, but the Warthog GraphQL extension makes this easier. Right-clicking on any field in operations or schemas gives you the ability to jump to (or peek at) definitions, as well as find any other references to that field in your project.
) of a schema. This is useful for developing on a future development schema and preparing your clients to conform to that schema. To switch between schema variants, open the Command Palette (
on mac), search "Warthog" and choose the "Warthog: Select Schema Tag" option.
The most common errors are configuration errors, like a missing
file or incorrect service information in the
Other errors may be caused from an old version of a published schema. To reload a schema, open the Command Palette (
on mac), search "Warthog" and choose the "Warthog: Reload Schema" option.

Sometimes errors will show up as a notification at the bottom of your editor. Other, less critical, messages may be shown in the output pane of the editor. To open the output pane and get diagnostic information about the extension and the current service loaded (if working with a client project), just click the "Warthog GraphQL" icon in the status bar at the bottom.
